While Caesar was con- sidering the application, Quintus Tubero brought an action against Ligarius, charging that he had resisted Caesar and allied himself with Juba, king of Numidia, an enemy of the state. eicero’s Cicero conducted the case for the accused with the most speech. consummate skill, adroitly impugning Tubero's motiveS, touch- ing the question of guilt only in the most casual way, and throw- ing himself wholly upon Caesar's mercy. The speech is of conspicuous literary merit. Its simple direct style, in striking contrast to the sonorous periods which Cicero would have addressed to a different court, its fine flavor of irony, its pathos and delicate eulogy, could scarcely have been improved upon.
